## Approving the Memorandum of Understanding between the Government of the State of Kuwait (represented by the Competition Protection Agency) and the Government of the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia (represented by the General Authority for Competition) in the field of competition protection

- Having reviewed the Constitution,
- And the Amiri Order issued on 2 Dhu al-Qi'dah 1445 H, corresponding to 10 May 2024 M,
- And upon the submission of the Minister of Foreign Affairs,
- And with the approval of the Council of Ministers <orig>مجلس الوزراء</orig>,

**We have decreed the following**

### Article One
The Memorandum of Understanding between the Government of the State of Kuwait (represented by the Competition Protection Agency <orig>جهاز حماية المنافسة</orig>) and the Government of the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia (represented by the General Authority for Competition <orig>الهيئة العامة للمنافسة</orig>) in the field of competition protection, signed in Kuwait City on 3/8/1446 H, corresponding to 2/2/2024 M, the text of which is attached to this decree, is hereby approved.

### Regarding the Appointment of a Non-Resident Ambassador

- And Law No. 21 of 1962 regarding the Diplomatic and Consular Corps System <orig>نظام السلكين الدبلوماسي والقنصلي</orig>, and its amending laws,
- And based on the recommendation of the Minister of Foreign Affairs <orig>وزير الخارجية</orig>,
- And after the approval of the Council of Ministers <orig>مجلس الوزراء</orig>,

**We have decreed the following:**

### Article One
Mr. Mohammed Yaqoub Hayati <orig>محمد يعقوب حياتي</orig> – Ambassador of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> to the Kingdom of Sweden <orig>مملكة السويد</orig> – shall be appointed, in addition to his current duties, as a non-resident Ambassador <orig>سفيراً محالاً</orig> of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> to the Kingdom of Denmark <orig>مملكة الدنمارك</orig>.

## Article Two
(Areas of Cooperation)
Through the conclusion of this Memorandum, the Parties seek to enhance cooperation in the fields of promoting competition and combating monopolistic practices and other practices restricting legitimate competition, and to build an integrated model for bilateral programs. The areas of cooperation focus on the following:

1- Exchange of information and experts in the field of promoting competition and combating monopolistic practices and other practices restricting legitimate competition, in a way that facilitates and enhances the performance of the Parties' tasks, especially with regard to the role of competitive guidance and how to formulate policies that promote competition in the markets of both countries.
2- Organizing conferences, visits, and training courses in the field of competition protection, its regulations, laws, and policies.
3- Exchange of expertise regarding investigation and inquiry procedures concerning violations of competition regulations and laws.
4- Exchange of consultations and experiences through mutual visits to the headquarters of competition authorities in both countries and through digital electronic communication channels and other means of communication between experts and technicians affiliated with both Parties on matters of common interest.
5- Exchange of experiences regarding the mechanism for examining complaints, requests, and notifications.
6- Exchange of studies and publications necessary for analyzing different market practices to detect monopolistic practices and situations harmful to competition.
7- Exchange of periodic bulletins, procedures, and measures in the field of competition protection.
8- Exchange of expertise on legislative issues and rules to achieve the desired sufficiency in the field of competition.
9- Any other activity agreed upon by the Parties.

## Article Three
(Confidentiality of Information)
1- Each of the Parties undertakes to maintain the confidentiality of private or confidential information and data exchanged in implementation of this Memorandum and joint cooperation programs, and not to disclose them to others.
2- If information obtained by either Party based on this Memorandum is required for any judicial proceeding, it must be requested in accordance with the regulations applicable to mutual legal assistance in judicial matters, as practiced by each Party.

## Article Four
(Intellectual Property)
Each Party retains the intellectual property rights to its works and information exchanged in any form with the other Party. Neither Party may publish or use the results of the other Party's studies exchanged in implementation of this Memorandum except after obtaining written consent from that Party.

## Article Five
(Expenses)
Each Party shall bear its own expenses related to the implementation of this Memorandum – according to its available capabilities – unless the Parties agree otherwise.

# Decree No. 144 of 2025
## Approving the Air Services Agreement between the Government of the State of Kuwait and the Government of the Republic of Tunisia and its Annexed Route Schedule

- Having reviewed the Constitution,
- And the Amiri Order <orig>الأمر الأميري</orig> issued on 2 Dhu al-Qi'dah 1445 AH corresponding to May 10, 2024 AD,
- And Decree-Law No. 108 of 1976 <orig>المرسوم بالقانون رقم 108 لسنة 1976</orig> exempting Arab and foreign airlines from taxes, as amended by Decree-Law No. 53 of 1979 <orig>المرسوم بالقانون رقم 53 لسنة 1979</orig>.
- And Decree No. 101 of 1996 <orig>المرسوم رقم 101 لسنة 1996</orig> approving a Protocol concerning the authentic five-language text of the Convention on International Civil Aviation (Chicago 1944),
- And Decree No. 104 of 2000 <orig>المرسوم رقم 104 لسنة 2000</orig> approving a Protocol concerning the authentic six-language text of the Convention on International Civil Aviation (Chicago 1944),
- And based on the submission of the Minister of Foreign Affairs,
- And after the approval of the Council of Ministers,

**We have decreed the following:**

### Article One
Approval of the Air Services Agreement between the Government of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> and the Government of the Republic of Tunisia <orig>الجمهورية التونسية</orig>, signed in the Republic of Tunisia <orig>جمهورية تونس</orig> on 26/4/2025, and its annexed Route Schedule, the texts of which are attached to this Decree.

### Article Two
Ministers – each within their respective jurisdiction – shall implement this Decree, which shall come into force from the date of its publication in the Official Gazette <orig>الجريدة الرسمية</orig>.

# Article Six
## (Settlement of Disputes)
Disputes arising from the interpretation, application, or implementation of this Memorandum shall be settled through direct communications between the Parties. In the event that an agreement is not reached, the dispute shall be settled through diplomatic channels between the Parties, and it shall not be submitted to any court, body, or other entity for settlement.

# Article Seven
## (Independent Programs and Annexes)
The Parties may conclude independent programs or annexes within the framework of this Memorandum, specifying the agreed-upon activities, the method and scope of participation for each Party, financial aspects, and any other necessary arrangements.

# Article Eight
## (Entry into Force, Amendments, and Termination)
1- This Memorandum shall enter into force from the date of the last mutual notification between the Parties – through diplomatic channels – confirming the completion of the necessary internal legal procedures.
2- The duration of this Memorandum is (four) years, and it shall be automatically renewed for a similar period or periods, unless one Party notifies the other Party in writing – through diplomatic channels – of its desire to terminate or not renew it at least (six) months prior to the specified date of its termination or expiry.
3- This Memorandum may be amended at any time based on the written consent of both Parties, and in accordance with the legal procedures followed by each of them. The amendment shall enter into force according to the procedures stipulated in paragraph (1) of this Article.
4- In the event of the termination of this Memorandum, its provisions shall remain in effect with respect to projects and programs that originated within its framework or based on it, unless the Parties agree otherwise through diplomatic channels.

This Memorandum was drawn up in the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> on 03/08/1446 AH corresponding to 02/02/2024 AD, in two original copies in the Arabic language.

For the Government of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig>

2. "Agreed Services" means scheduled international air services on the routes specified in the Annex to this Agreement for the carriage of passengers, cargo, goods, and mail in accordance with the agreed and authorized capacity.
3. "Specified Routes" means the routes defined in the Annex to this Agreement, or as amended in accordance with the provisions of Article (19) of this Agreement.
4. "Agreement" means this Agreement, its Annexes, and any amendments to this Agreement or its Annexes.
5. "Air Service", "International Air Service", "Air Transport Enterprise", and "Stop for Non-Commercial Purposes" have the meanings respectively provided for in Article (96) of the Convention.
6. "Ordinary Equipment" means materials used on the aircraft during the flight, including initial relief and rescue equipment, excluding furniture sets and their various parts.
7. "Convention" means the Convention on International Civil Aviation opened for signature at Chicago on the seventh day of December 1944, and includes any Annex adopted under Article (90) of that Convention, and any amendments to the Annexes or the Convention under Articles (90) and (94), provided that such Annexes and amendments are effective for both Contracting Parties.
8. "Designated Air Transport Enterprise" means any air transport enterprise designated in writing by one Contracting Party to the other Contracting Party in accordance with Article (3) of this Agreement as the air transport enterprise entitled to operate the Agreed Services on the specified routes in accordance with Article (2) of this Agreement.
9. "Spare Parts" means materials intended for the repair or replacement of aircraft parts, including engines.
10. "Tariff" means any fare, fee, or charge for the carriage of passengers, baggage, cargo, or mail in air transport (including any other related means of transport), collected by airlines, including their agents, as well as the conditions governing the availability of such fares, fees, or charges.
11. "Territory" in relation to a State shall be interpreted as defined in Article (2) of the Convention.
12. "Usage Charges" means charges imposed on air transport enterprises for the use of an airport, air navigation services, aviation security facilities, or other related services and facilities.
13. "Capacity" in relation to an aircraft, means the permissible payload on an aircraft on a specified air route, from an air route, and in relation to specified air services, the capacity of the aircraft used in providing that service multiplied by the number of flights performed by that aircraft during a specific period on a specified air route or part of an air route.

## Article 2:
### Grant of Rights

1. Each Contracting Party grants to the other Contracting Party the rights specified in this Agreement to enable its designated air transport enterprises to establish and exploit/operate international air services on the route schedule specified in the Annex.
2. Subject to the provisions of this Agreement, the enterprise designated by each Contracting Party shall enjoy the following rights:
    a. The right to fly across the territory of the other Contracting Party without landing.
    b. The right to land in the territory of the other Contracting Party for non-commercial purposes.
    c. The right to land in the territory of the other Contracting Party when operating the international air services specified in the Annex to this Agreement for the purpose of taking on and/or discharging international traffic of passengers, cargo, and mail from and to the territory of the other Contracting Party, separately or combined, during the operation of the agreed air routes.
3. Enterprises belonging to one of the Contracting Parties, other than those designated in accordance with Article 3 (Designation and Authorization), may enjoy the rights specified in points (a) and (b) of paragraph (2) of this Article.
4. Nothing in the provisions of paragraph (2) of this Article shall be construed as permitting a designated enterprise of a Contracting Party the right to take on and/or discharge passengers, cargo, and mail from the territory of the other Contracting Party for remuneration for carriage between points within the territory of that other Contracting Party.

Each Contracting Party shall have the right to designate in writing, through diplomatic channels, to the other Contracting Party one or more air transport enterprises for the purpose of operating the agreed services on the specified routes in accordance with this Agreement. Such designation may also be withdrawn or replaced.

2. Upon receipt of such designation, and upon request by the designated air transport enterprise in the manner and procedures followed by each Contracting Party, each Contracting Party shall grant to the other the appropriate authorization for operation with the least possible procedural delay for the exercise of the rights specified in Article (2) of this Agreement, provided that the following conditions are met:
    a. The principal place of business of the air transport enterprise is in the territory of the Contracting Party designating that enterprise, and
    b. Substantial ownership and effective control of the enterprise are vested in the Contracting Party designating the enterprise or in its nationals, or both, and
    c. The enterprise holds a valid Air Operator Certificate (AOC) <orig>شهادة مشغل جوي (ش.م.ج)</orig> issued by the Contracting Party designating it, in accordance with the laws in force in the territory of the Contracting Party designating the enterprise, and
    d. The Contracting Party designating the air transport enterprise applies the provisions specified in Article (16) Air Safety and Article (17) Aviation Security of this Agreement, and
    e. The designated enterprise must satisfy the conditions imposed on it by the specific laws and regulations normally applied to the operation of international air services by the Contracting Party receiving the designation.

3. Upon receipt of the designation and operating authorization referred to in paragraph (2) of this Article, the designated air transport enterprise may at any time begin to operate the agreed services, provided that the flight schedule is clarified in accordance with the provisions of Article (12) of this Agreement for the approval of the flight schedule and the application of the provisions of this Agreement by the air transport enterprise.

# Article 4:
## Refusal, Suspension, and Limitation of Authorizations

1. The aeronautical authorities of each Contracting Party shall have the right to refuse to grant the authorization referred to in Article (3) Designation and Authorization of this Agreement to an airline designated by the other Contracting Party, or to revoke, suspend, or impose conditions on such authorization, temporarily or permanently, in any case:
    1. if the designated airline cannot maintain its principal place of business in the territory of the Contracting Party that designated it, or
    2. if the aeronautical authorities are not satisfied that substantial ownership and effective control of the airline are not vested in the Contracting Party designating the airline or in its nationals, or both, and
    3. if it is proven that the airline does not hold a valid Air Operator Certificate (AOC) <orig>شهادة مشغل جوي</orig> issued by that Contracting Party in accordance with the laws in force in the territory of the Contracting Party that designated the airline, or
    4. in the event of the failure of the Contracting Party designating the airline to apply the provisions contained in Article (16) Air Safety and Article (17) Aviation Security of this Agreement, or
    5. in the event that the airline fails to comply with the laws and regulations normally applied by the aeronautical authorities of the Contracting Party in accordance with the Agreement.
2. Unless it is necessary to take immediate action for a violation of the laws and regulations referred to above, or unless action is required in accordance with the provisions of Articles (16) or (17) relating to safety or security, the rights contained in paragraph (1) of this Article shall not be exercised except after consultations between the aeronautical authorities, in accordance with Article (18) Consultations of this Agreement.

# Article 5:

1. The laws, regulations, and procedures in force in the territory of each Contracting Party relating to the entry into and departure from its territory of passengers, crew, cargo, and mail on aircraft (including laws and regulations concerning entry and exit, authorizations, aviation security, and immigration

## Article 6: Recognition of Certificates and Licenses

Certificates of airworthiness, certificates of competency, and licenses issued or validated by one of the Contracting Parties, and which are still in force, shall be recognized as valid by the other Contracting Party for the purpose of operating the agreed services provided by this Agreement, provided that the requirements under which such certificates and licenses were issued or validated are equal to or exceed the minimum standards established or to be established pursuant to the Convention.
2. Each Contracting Party reserves the right to refuse to recognize certificates of airworthiness, competency, and licenses for flights over its territory granted or recognized in favor of its nationals by the other Contracting Party.

# Article 7
## Exemption from Customs Duties/Taxes and Other Charges

1. Each Contracting Party shall, to the fullest extent possible on a reciprocal basis, exempt the designated airline of the other Contracting Party, under its national law, from import restrictions, customs duties, local goods taxes, inspection fees, and other national fees and taxes on aircraft, their fuel, lubricating oils, consumable and technical supplies, spare parts including engines, aircraft equipment, and other items such as printed ticket stock, printed materials bearing the airline's logo, and promotional materials for the designated airline, intended for use solely in connection with the operation or servicing of the aircraft of the designated airline of the other Contracting Party in the agreed air service.
2. The exemptions granted under this Article shall apply to the items mentioned in paragraph (1) of this Article, with the exception of charges for services rendered, provided that:
    1. They are introduced into the territory of the other Contracting Party or on its behalf.
    2. They remain on board the aircraft of a designated airline of one of the Contracting Parties upon arrival in the territory of the other Contracting Party until its departure and/or are consumed during flight over that territory.
    3. They are loaded onto the aircraft of the designated airline of one of the Contracting Parties in the territory of the other Contracting Party for use on board aircraft used in the agreed international services. This applies regardless of whether these items are used entirely within the territory of the Contracting Party granting the exemption, provided that ownership of these items is not transferred in the said Contracting Party's territory.
    4. Baggage and cargo in direct transit.
3. Normal airborne equipment, as well as materials and supplies normally kept on board the aircraft of either Contracting Party, may be unloaded in the territory of the other Party, provided that

In such a case, these items shall be placed under the supervision of the said authorities until they are re-exported or take another destination in accordance with the customs laws and procedures of that Contracting Party.

## Article 8
### Principles Governing the Operation of the Agreed Services

1. Fair and equal opportunities shall be available to the designated airlines of each Contracting Party to operate the agreed services. Each Contracting Party shall take any appropriate measures in accordance with its laws to avoid all forms of discrimination, unfair competition, or actions detrimental to the interests of the designated airline of the other Contracting Party when exercising its rights, which are not in conformity with the provisions of this Agreement.
2. When operating the agreed services, the designated airlines of each Contracting Party shall take into consideration the interests of the designated airlines of the other Contracting Party so as not to unduly affect the operation of the services invested by the latter on all or part of the same routes.
3. The capacity provided by the designated airline(s) of the Contracting Parties shall be consistent with the requirements for the carriage of passengers, cargo, and mail. The primary objective shall be to provide a reasonable load factor and sufficient capacity to meet the current and actual demands for the carriage of passengers, baggage, goods, and mail to and from the territory of the Contracting Party that designated the airline.
4. Both Contracting Parties shall take all necessary measures within their respective jurisdictions to prevent any form of discrimination and to reduce administrative burdens related to filing requirements and procedures for the designated airline of the other Contracting Party.

1. The designated enterprise(s) of one Contracting Party shall, on the basis of reciprocity, have the right to maintain representation in the territory of the other Contracting Party for the promotion and sale of air transport services.
2. In accordance with the applicable laws, regulations, and rules of each Contracting Party, the designated enterprise(s) of one Contracting Party shall have the right to employ and maintain in the territory of the other Contracting Party administrative, sales, technical, operational, and other specialist staff to perform these activities.
3. Subject to the exception in paragraph (4) of this Article, the designated enterprises of both Contracting Parties shall have the right to use the services and personnel of any other organization, company, or airline operating in the territory of the other Contracting Party and licensed to perform such activities in the territory of that other Contracting Party.
4. In the event of the nomination of a general agent or a general sales agent, such agent must be appointed in accordance with the relevant laws and regulations applicable to each Contracting Party.
5. In accordance with the national laws and regulations applicable to each Contracting Party, each designated enterprise shall have the right to engage in the sale of air transport services in the territory of the other Contracting Party, either directly or through its agents, and any person shall be free to purchase such services.
6. The designated enterprise of one Contracting Party shall have the right to pay its expenses in the territory of the other Contracting Party in local currency or in convertible currency, in accordance with the applicable exchange regulations.
7. The activities provided for in paragraphs (1) to (4) above shall be exercised in accordance with the laws and regulations of the other Contracting Party, and the Contracting Parties undertake that the laws, regulations, and rules shall be applied in a non-discriminatory manner and consistent with the purposes of this Agreement.
8. The provision of ground handling services for the aircraft of the designated enterprises of a Contracting Party shall be subject to the regulations/rules and legislation in force for each Contracting Party.

Both Contracting Parties shall permit the designated air transport enterprise to establish tariffs for air services based on commercial market considerations, including operating costs, service characteristics, user interests, reasonable profit, and any other market considerations.

2. Either Contracting Party may require notification or filing of the tariffs to be charged by the designated enterprise of itself or of the other Contracting Party. The tariffs shall remain in effect unless they are subsequently disapproved in accordance with paragraph (4) of this Article.

3. Without prejudice to the applicable and prevailing competition and consumer protection laws of each Contracting Party, neither Contracting Party shall take unilateral action to prevent the initiation or continuation of a proposed tariff by a designated enterprise of the other Contracting Party related to the international air services provided for in this Agreement. Intervention as described in paragraph (4) below shall be limited to:
    a. Prevention of any unreasonable discriminatory prices or practices.
    b. Protection of consumers from unreasonably high or restrictive prices due to the abuse of a dominant position or due to concerted practices among air transport enterprises.
    c. Protection of air transport enterprises from artificially low prices.

4. Without prejudice to the provisions of paragraph (3) of this Article, the aviation authorities of either Contracting Party may disapprove a tariff submitted by the air transport enterprises of the other Contracting Party if the aviation authorities believe that the proposed tariff by the transport enterprises is not consistent with the provisions of paragraph (3) of this Article. In such a case, the concerned aviation authority shall do the following:
    a. Send a notice of dissatisfaction to the aviation authorities of the other Contracting Party and to the designated air transport enterprise as soon as possible, and within a period of not less than thirty (30) days from the date of sending the notice or the filing of the tariff.

b. by requesting consultations in accordance with the procedures followed in paragraph (5) of this Article. Unless the two Parties agree in writing to reject the proposed tariff, this tariff shall be deemed disapproved.

5. The aeronautical authorities of each Contracting Party may request consultations with the aeronautical authorities of the other Contracting Party regarding any tariff imposed by the air transport enterprise of the other Contracting Party for international air transport services to or from the territory of the first Contracting Party, including tariffs for which a notice of disapproval has been submitted. These consultations shall be held within a period not exceeding fifteen (15) days from the date of receipt of the request.

6. The aeronautical authorities of both Contracting Parties shall cooperate in providing the necessary information to reach a reasonable solution to the disputed matter. Upon reaching an agreement on the tariff for which a notice of disapproval has been sent, the aeronautical authorities of both Parties shall exert their utmost efforts to put this agreement into effect. In the event that no mutual agreement is reached in this regard, the tariff shall enter into force or continue to be applied.

## Article 12: Approval of Flight Schedules

1. The designated airline of each Contracting Party shall submit its programmed flight schedules for approval to the civil aeronautical authorities of the other Contracting Party at least sixty (60) days prior to the operation of the agreed routes. The same procedure shall apply to any amendment to the schedules.

2. As for additional flights that the designated airline of one Contracting Party wishes to operate on the agreed routes outside the approved schedule, the said designated airline must request prior permission from the aeronautical authorities of the other Contracting Party. Such requests are usually submitted at least one working week before the scheduled operation of those flights.

3. The civil aeronautical authorities receiving these operating schedules shall approve them or propose any amendments thereto. In all cases, the designated airlines shall not commence their services before the schedules are approved by the concerned civil aeronautical authorities, and this principle applies to subsequent amendments.

## Article 13:
### Provision of Information
The civil aviation authorities of one Contracting Party shall provide, or shall require their designated enterprises to provide, the civil aviation authorities of the other Contracting Party, upon request, with periodic statistics or other data that may reasonably be required for reviewing the operation of the agreed services. These statistics shall include, but not be limited to, statistical data relating to traffic carried by their carriers between points in the territory of the other Contracting Party and other points on the specified routes.

## Article 14:
### Transfer of Excess Revenues
In accordance with the national laws and regulations of each Contracting Party, each Contracting Party shall grant the enterprises designated by the other Contracting Party the right to transfer excess revenues over expenses incurred by those designated enterprises in its territory resulting from the carriage of passengers, cargo, and mail, in any convertible currency, in accordance with the exchange rate prevailing in both Contracting Parties.

## Article 15:
### User Charges
1. Neither Contracting Party shall impose, or permit to be imposed, user charges or fees on the air transport enterprises designated by the other Contracting Party that are higher than those imposed on its own air transport enterprises operating similar international services.
2. Each Contracting Party shall exert its best efforts to ensure that the charges for the use of high-quality public airports and air navigation facilities, which are imposed or permitted to be imposed by the competent authorities on the designated enterprises of the other Contracting Party, are fair and reasonable.
3. Each Contracting Party shall encourage consultations regarding user charges between the competent authority imposing user charges, or the airport service provider or air navigation service provider, and the air transport enterprises using those services and facilities provided by those authorities or service providers.

# Article 16: Aviation Safety

1. Either Contracting Party may request consultations at any time concerning the safety standards of the other Contracting Party in the areas related to flight crew, aircraft, and aircraft operation. Such consultations shall be held within thirty (30) days from the date of such request.
2. Following such consultation, if one Contracting Party finds that the other Contracting Party does not ensure the effective implementation of safety standards in the areas referred to in paragraph (1) in a manner that meets the standards established at that time pursuant to the Convention, the other Contracting Party shall be informed of such findings and the steps deemed necessary to comply with the standards prescribed under the Convention. The other Contracting Party shall then take appropriate corrective action within fifteen (15) days or any agreed period. If the other Contracting Party fails to take such action within the agreed period, this shall constitute a basis for the application of Article (4) of this Agreement.
3. Notwithstanding the obligations mentioned in Article (16) and Article (33) of the Convention, it has been agreed that when an aircraft of a specific enterprise or enterprises belonging to one Contracting Party performs air services to or from the territory of the other Contracting Party, while present within the territory of the other Contracting Party, the Contracting Party may subject the aircraft to examination, internally and externally, to verify the validity of the aircraft's and its crew's documents, and the apparent airworthiness and equipment of the aircraft (referred to in this Article as "ramp inspection"), provided that this does not lead to an unacceptable delay in the aircraft's departure.
4. If a ramp inspection or a series of ramp inspections results in:
    a. serious concern that the aircraft or its operation does not meet the minimum standards applicable at that time in accordance with the Convention, or
    b. serious concern that there is a deficiency in maintaining and adhering to the safety standards applicable at that time in accordance with the Convention,
    then the Contracting Party conducting the inspection is free, for the purpose of Article (33) of the Convention, to conclude that the requirements on the basis of which a certificate or license was issued for that aircraft or its crew, or made valid, are not in conformity with or exceed the minimum standards established under the Convention.

5. If a representative of a particular air transport enterprise (or enterprises) of one Contracting Party refuses to grant permission for an area inspection of their aircraft in accordance with paragraph (3) of this Article, the other Contracting Party shall be free to infer the existence of serious concerns as referred to in paragraph (4) of this Article, and may draw the conclusions mentioned in that paragraph.

6. Each Contracting Party reserves the right to immediately suspend or amend the operating authorization granted to an air transport enterprise of the other Contracting Party if it concludes that such immediate action is necessary to ensure the safety of the air transport enterprise's operations, based on the outcome of an area inspection or a series of area inspections, or the refusal to permit such inspection, or the outcome of any consultations held.

7. Any action taken by one Contracting Party under paragraphs (2) and (6) of this Article shall be discontinued if the basis for taking such action ceases to exist.

8. With reference to paragraph (2) of this Article, if it is determined that one Contracting Party has remained in non-compliance with the standard rules of the International Civil Aviation Organization <orig>منظمة الطيران المدني الدولي</orig> upon the expiry of the agreed period, the Secretary General of the International Civil Aviation Organization <orig>منظمة الطيران المدني الدولي</orig> shall be informed thereof, and shall also be informed of the satisfactory resolution of this situation.

## Article 17
### Aviation Security

1. The Contracting Parties affirm, in conformity with their rights and obligations under international law, that their obligation to each other to protect the security of civil aviation against acts of unlawful interference forms an integral part of this Agreement. Without limiting the generality of their rights and obligations under international law, the Contracting Parties shall act in particular in accordance with the provisions of the Convention on Offences and Certain Other Acts Committed on Board Aircraft, signed in Tokyo on 14 September 1963, the Convention for the Suppression of Unlawful Seizure of Aircraft, signed in The Hague on 16 December 1970, the Convention for the Suppression of Unlawful Acts against the Safety of Civil Aviation, signed in Montreal on 23 September 1971, as well as the Supplementary Protocol to that Convention for the Suppression of Unlawful Acts of Violence at Airports Serving International Civil Aviation, signed in Montreal on 24 February 1988, and the Convention on the Marking of Plastic Explosives for the Purpose of Detection, signed in Montreal on 1 March 1991, and without prejudice to the interests of the Contracting Parties from any other convention or protocol relating to civil aviation security.

2. 3. In addition, the Contracting Parties shall require that operators of aircraft of their registry or operators who have their principal place of business or permanent residence in their territory, and the operators of airports in their territory, act in conformity with such aviation security provisions.

4. Each Contracting Party agrees that such operators may be required to observe the security provisions referred to in paragraph (3) above, which are required by the other Contracting Party for entry into, while within, or departure from the territory of that other Contracting Party. Each Contracting Party shall ensure that adequate measures are effectively applied within its territory to protect the aircraft and to inspect passengers, crew, carry-on items, baggage, cargo, and aircraft stores prior to and during boarding or loading. Each Contracting Party agrees to give positive consideration to any request from the other Contracting Party for reasonable special security measures to meet a particular threat.

5. When an incident or threat of unlawful seizure of civil aircraft or other unlawful acts against the safety of such aircraft, their passengers and crew, airports or air navigation facilities and services occurs, the Contracting Parties shall cooperate by facilitating communications and other appropriate measures intended to terminate such incident or threat thereof, quickly and safely.

6. Each Contracting Party shall notify the other Contracting Party of any differences between its national regulations and practices relating to aviation security and the aviation security standards contained in the Convention. Either Contracting Party may request immediate consultations with the other Contracting Party concerning any such differences.

## Article 18
### Consultations

1. Any Contracting Party may, at any time, request consultations regarding the application, interpretation, or amendment of this Agreement.
2. These consultations shall take place between the authorities or by correspondence within sixty (60) days from the date of receipt by the other Contracting Party of a written request through diplomatic channels, unless the two Contracting Parties agree otherwise.

## Article 19
### Amendment of the Agreement

1. If one of the Contracting Parties wishes to amend any article of this Agreement, such amendment shall be made in accordance with the provisions of Article 18 (Consultations). The agreed amendments shall enter into force after the completion of the constitutional legal procedures of each Contracting Party, and from the date agreed upon through the exchange of diplomatic notes, and the amendments shall be considered an integral part of this Agreement.
2. Notwithstanding the provisions of paragraph (1) of this Article, the aeronautical authorities of the two Contracting Parties may directly agree on amendments to the Annex of this Agreement. These amendments shall apply from a date to be agreed upon and shall enter into force upon their confirmation through diplomatic channels.
3. If the amendments relate only to the route schedule, consultations shall be held between the aeronautical authorities of the two Contracting Parties. When these authorities agree on a new or modified route schedule, the agreed amendments shall become effective as soon as they are confirmed on the day agreed upon by the civil aviation authorities.

4. This Agreement shall be automatically amendable by the provisions of any international convention or multilateral treaty to which the Contracting Parties may become parties. Any consultations aimed at determining the extent to which this Agreement is to be terminated, suspended, amended, or supplemented in accordance with the provisions of the aforementioned international convention or multilateral treaty shall be in accordance with Article (18) Consultations of this Agreement.

## Article 20
### Settlement of Disputes

1. If a dispute arises between the Contracting Parties concerning the interpretation or application of this Agreement, the Contracting Parties shall first endeavor to settle it through negotiations between the civil aviation authorities of both countries.
2. If the civil aviation authorities fail to settle the dispute through negotiations, the dispute shall be settled through diplomatic channels.
3. If the settlement is not reached in accordance with paragraph (1) or (2) of this Article, the dispute shall, at the request of either Contracting Party, be referred to an arbitral tribunal composed of three arbitrators, constituted as follows:
   - a. Each of the Contracting Parties shall appoint one arbitrator, and the third shall be appointed by agreement between the two appointed arbitrators. The latter shall preside over this arbitral tribunal.
   - b. Each of the Contracting Parties shall appoint its arbitrator within a period of sixty (60) days from the date of receipt of notification from one Contracting Party to the other Contracting Party through diplomatic channels requesting arbitration of the dispute by a third international body within a maximum period of another sixty (60) days.
   - c. If one of the Contracting Parties fails to appoint an arbitrator within the specified period, or if the third arbitrator is not appointed during the specified period, the President of the Council of the International Civil Aviation Organization <orig>منظمة الطيران المدني الدولي</orig> may, at the request of either Contracting Party, appoint an arbitrator or arbitrators as required. When the President is unable, his deputy may perform this task. In this case, the arbitrator or arbitrators appointed by the said President or his deputy, as required, shall not be nationals of the States concerned by this Agreement or have their permanent residence therein.
4. The arbitral tribunal shall determine the principles of arbitration in accordance with this Agreement and establish its procedures.

## Article 21:
### Registration of the Agreement and its Amendments

This Agreement and all subsequent amendments shall be registered by the two Contracting Parties with the International Civil Aviation Organization <orig>منظمة الطيران المدني الدولي</orig>.

## Article 22:
### Termination of the Agreement

1. Either of the Contracting Parties may, at any time after the entry into force of this Agreement, notify the other Contracting Party in writing, through diplomatic channels, of its decision to terminate this Agreement, and this notification shall be simultaneously communicated to the International Civil Aviation Organization <orig>منظمة الطيران المدني الدولي</orig>. This Agreement shall terminate one (1) year after the date of receipt of the notification by the other Contracting Party.
2. In the absence of acknowledgment of receipt of the notification by the other Contracting Party, the notification shall be deemed to have been received fourteen (14) days after the date of its receipt by the International Civil Aviation Organization <orig>منظمة الطيران المدني الدولي</orig>.

### Article 23:
### Entry into Force

This Agreement shall enter into force after the completion of the necessary internal legal procedures by each Contracting Party, and each Party shall notify the other of the completion of these procedures through the exchange of diplomatic notes.

This Agreement shall enter into force on the first day of the month following the date of receipt of the last notification. Upon its entry into force, it shall supersede the Agreement between the Government of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> and the Government of the Republic of Tunisia <orig>الجمهورية التونسية</orig> concerning Air Transport, signed by the Parties on December 9, 1975.
In witness thereof, the undersigned, being duly authorized by their respective Governments, have signed this Agreement.

Done in the Republic of Tunisia <orig>جمهورية تونس</orig> on the 26th day of April 2025 AD, in two original copies, each in the Arabic language, both having equal legal validity.

# Memorandum of Understanding
## In the Field of Exchange of Manpower in the Private Sector Between the Government of the State of Kuwait and the Government of the Republic of Tunisia

The Government of the State of Kuwait, represented by the Public Authority for Manpower <orig>الهيئة العامة للقوى العاملة</orig>, and the Government of the Republic of Tunisia, represented by the Ministry of Employment and Vocational Training <orig>وزارة التشغيل والتكوين المهني</orig>, hereinafter referred to as "the Two Parties," affirming the existing fraternal and friendly relations between the governments and peoples of the two countries, and desiring to establish bilateral relations on the basis of mutual interest, and wishing to enhance cooperation and coordination in the field of manpower exchange,
The Two Parties have agreed as follows:

### Article (1)
This Memorandum aims to strengthen cooperation in the field of labor, employment, and workforce development, and to emphasize the importance of protection granted to expatriate workers in accordance with the legislation in force in both countries.

### Article (2)
The Two Parties shall facilitate the provision of relevant services to adopt and develop such cooperation within the framework of the prevailing laws, provisions, and legislation in both countries.

### Article (3)
1. The Two Parties shall facilitate the movement and recruitment of manpower for citizens of both countries and establish rules and regulations that ensure the implementation of this agreement.
2. The Two Parties shall work to identify their manpower needs in each specialization within the private sector and provide the other Party with secondment offers that include the job description, academic qualification, required specialization, years of experience, and privileges granted to each position.
3. The Two Parties shall work to encourage twinning operations between the employment-related structures in both countries and establish a partnership that enables the support of talent employment and the exchange of information between these structures.

### Article (4)
The Two Parties shall exchange visits between the two countries and exchange experiences and knowledge in the field of job creation and employment opportunities.

### Article (5)
The basic terms of employment and the rights and duties of both the employer and the worker shall be specified in the employment contract, which must be drafted in accordance with the laws and legislation of the host country.

### Article (6)
In the event of a dispute between the employer and the worker, efforts shall be made to settle the dispute amicably in accordance with the regulations and legislation in force in the host country. If an amicable solution is not reached, the dispute shall be referred to the competent judicial authority.

### Article (7)
Manpower from both Parties may remit their funds to their home country in accordance with the law applicable in both countries.

### Article (8)
A joint working group shall be formed to carry out the following tasks:
1. Confirm the implementation of the Memorandum.

# Decree No. 146 of 2025
## Approving an Agreement between the Government of the State of Kuwait and the Government of the Federal Republic of Nigeria regarding the Establishment of a Joint Committee for Cooperation

-Having reviewed the Constitution,
-And Amiri Order issued on 2 Dhul-Qa'dah 1445 AH corresponding to 10 May 2024 AD,
-And based on the presentation of the Minister of Foreign Affairs,
-And after the approval of the Council of Ministers,

**We have decreed the following:**

### Article One
Approval of the Agreement between the Government of the State of Kuwait and the Government of the Federal Republic of Nigeria regarding the establishment of a Joint Committee for Cooperation, signed in Kuwait City <orig>مدينة الكويت</orig> on 5 February 2025, the texts of which are attached to this Decree.

### Article Two
Ministers – each within their respective jurisdiction – shall implement this Decree, and it shall come into force from the date of its publication in the Official Gazette.

## Agreement between the Government of the State of Kuwait and the Government of the Federal Republic of Nigeria on the Establishment of a Joint Committee for Cooperation

The Government of the State of Kuwait and the Government of the Federal Republic of Nigeria (hereinafter referred to as "the Parties" and individually as "the Party"),
Desirous of strengthening friendly relations and mutual cooperation between their two countries in various fields,
And recognizing the importance of the Joint Committee in an effort to continue the effective and strong partnership between the two countries,
Have agreed as follows:

2. Interpreting the provisions of this Memorandum, settling any difficulties that may arise during its implementation, and proposing a review or definition of some of its provisions.
3. Studying newly created job opportunities, proposing technical cooperation procedures, skill development, and providing all sectors with skilled technical workers with the aim of achieving the common interests of both Parties.
4. The Joint Working Group shall meet once every year alternately in both countries, and whenever the need arises, upon the request of either Party.

### Article (9)
1. This Memorandum of Understanding shall not affect the obligations arising from bilateral, regional, and international agreements to which either Party is a signatory.
2. The Parties shall implement this Memorandum of Understanding in accordance with the laws and regulations in force in both countries.

### Article (10)
Any dispute that may arise from the interpretation or implementation of this Memorandum shall be settled amicably by both Parties through diplomatic channels.

### Article (11)
1. This Memorandum shall enter into force from the date of receipt of the last written notification by which either Party informs the other Party, through diplomatic channels, of the fulfillment of the necessary national legal requirements for its entry into force.
2. This Memorandum may be amended by written agreement of the Parties, and such amendments shall enter into force in accordance with the legal procedures followed in paragraph (1) of this Article.
3. This Memorandum shall remain in force for a period of (4) years and shall be automatically renewed for a similar period or periods unless one of the Parties notifies the other Party in writing, through diplomatic channels, of its desire to terminate it six (6) months prior to its expiration date.
4. The termination or expiration of this Memorandum shall not prejudice the completion of ongoing activities that have commenced implementation, until their completion, unless the Parties agree otherwise.

### Article (12)
This Memorandum supersedes the Memorandum of Understanding in the field of Labor and Social Affairs signed on 26 May 2016 in Tunis City <orig>مدينة تونس</orig>.
This Memorandum was drawn up in Tunis City <orig>مدينة تونس</orig> on Wednesday, 20 November 2024, in two original copies in Arabic, each having equal legal validity.

# Article 1
## Areas of Cooperation

The two Parties shall establish a Joint Committee, hereinafter referred to as "the Committee", to develop bilateral relations between them. It shall be entrusted with the following tasks:
    - a- Exchanging information and views on political matters of common interest;
    - b- Defense, security, cybersecurity, and counter-terrorism cooperation;
    - c- Economy, trade, and investment;
    - d- Education, higher education, scientific research, cultural, and artistic cooperation;
    - e- Consular cooperation, customs, and land, sea, and air transport;
    - f- Health cooperation, social services, social security, and cooperation in the fields of agriculture, livestock, and food security;
    - g- Any other areas of cooperation identified by the Parties.
2. Following up on agreements, treaties, and cooperation programs signed between the two Parties and working towards their full implementation.
3. Facilitating the exchange of information, expertise, and consultations between the two Parties in the areas of cooperation mentioned in paragraph (1) of this Article.

# Article 2
## Head of the Joint Committee
1. The Joint Committee shall be co-chaired by the Ministers of Foreign Affairs of the two Parties or their representatives.
2. Senior officials from the Ministries of Foreign Affairs of the two Parties, Undersecretaries, and experts/specialists concerned with bilateral cooperation issues, or their representatives from among senior officials, shall participate in the meetings of the Joint Committee.

# Article 3
## Time and Place of the Joint Committee
1. The Committee shall hold its ordinary sessions annually in the capital of each country, alternately, or exceptionally at the request of either Party.
2. The two Parties shall agree on the dates of the Committee's meetings through diplomatic channels.

# Article 4
## Working Group and Experts' Meeting
1. The two Parties shall, by mutual consent, establish working groups of experts responsible for preparing, following up, and coordinating the Committee's meetings.
2. The working group meetings shall precede the Committee meetings and shall be held in the same capital where the Committee meetings are held, as mentioned in paragraph (2) of Article 5.
3. The Minister of State <orig>وزير الدولة</orig> and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Nigeria <orig>وزارة خارجية نيجيريا</orig> and the Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs of Kuwait <orig>نائب وزير خارجية الكويت</orig> shall head their respective country's delegations to the working group meetings, which shall include representatives of the competent authorities in the areas to be discussed by the Committee in its meetings and listed on its agenda.
4. The working group may include a number of businessmen and members of the Chambers of Commerce and Industry <orig>غرفتي التجارة والصناعة</orig> in both countries, whenever the matter so requires.

# Article 5
## Committee's Agenda
1. The host Party shall prepare the draft agenda for the Joint Committee meeting and submit it to the other Party at least two months before the start of the meetings.
2. The working group shall formulate recommendations for inclusion in the agenda, provided that these recommendations are compiled and included in the minutes of the Committee meeting.

# Article 6
## Confidentiality
The two Parties shall adhere to the principle of confidentiality. All deliberations, documents, minutes, data, or official announcements issued by the body shall remain confidential and may not be circulated or published except by mutual agreement between the two Parties.

# Article 7
## Joint Implementation Committee
1. A Joint Implementation Committee <orig>لجنة التنفيذ المشتركة</orig> composed of experts from both Parties shall be established.
2. The Joint Implementation Committee <orig>لجنة التنفيذ المشتركة</orig> shall be chaired by a senior official from both Ministries of Foreign Affairs to implement the decisions of the previous annual session for the following year's annual session. The meeting shall be held in the capital of the host country for the next session.
3. The task of the Joint Implementation Committee <orig>لجنة التنفيذ المشتركة</orig> is to follow up on the implementation status of its previous decisions and submit a joint report thereon to the Committee.

# Article 8
## Dispute Settlement
Any disputes arising from the interpretation, application, or implementation of this Agreement shall be settled amicably through consultations or negotiations via diplomatic channels.

# Article 9
## Entry into Force, Amendments, Termination
1. This Agreement shall enter into force on the date of receipt of the last notification by which one Party informs the other Party, in writing and through diplomatic channels, of the fulfillment of its necessary national procedures for its entry into force.
2. This Agreement may be amended in writing by agreement of the Parties, at any time. Such amendments shall enter into force in accordance with the procedures set forth in paragraph 1 of this Article.
3. This Agreement shall remain in force for a period of five (5) years from the date of entry into force, and shall be automatically renewed for a similar period or periods, unless one Party

# AGREEMENT
## BETWEEN
## THE GOVERNMENT OF THE STATE OF KUWAIT
## AND
## THE GOVERNMENT OF THE FEDERAL REPUBLIC OF NIGERIA
## ON ESTABLISHMENT OF A JOINT COMMISSION FOR COOPERATION

The Government of the State of Kuwait and the Government of the Federal Republic of Nigeria (hereinafter jointly referred to as the "Parties" and singularly as the "Party)

DESIRING to promote friendly relations and mutual cooperation between their countries in various fields;

RECOGNIZING the importance of the Joint Commission in an effort to continue the effective and solid partnership between the Countries.

HAVE AGREED on the following:

## Article 1
### Fields of Cooperation
1. The Parties shall establish a Joint Commission hereinafter referred to as the "Commission" to develop bilateral relations between them.
It shall be entrusted with the following tasks:
a) Exchange of information and opinion on topics of a political nature of common interests;
b) Defence and security cooperation, cyber counterterrorism;
c) Economy, Trade and Investment;
d) Education, higher education and scientific, cultural and artistic research;
e) Consular cooperation, Customs, land, sea and air transport;
f) Health cooperation, social services, social security, and cooperation in the fields of agriculture, livestock and food security; and
g) Any other areas of cooperation as determined by the Parties.
2. Follow up on Agreements, Treaties and cooperation programs signed between the Parties and work on their full implementation.
3. Facilitate the exchange of information, experiences and consultations between the Parties in the areas of cooperation mentioned in Paragraph (1) of this Article.

## Article 2
### Head of Joint Commission
1. The Joint Commission shall be chaired by the Foreign Ministers of both Parties or their representatives.
2. Senior officials of the Ministries of Foreign Affairs of the Parties, Under Secretaries and Experts/Specialists on issues of bilateral cooperation or their representatives from among the Senior Officials shall participate in the Joint Commission Meetings.

## Article 3
### Time and Place of the Joint Commission
1. The Commission shall hold its regular sessions annually in the capital of each country, alternately, or exceptionally at the request of either Party.
2. The Parties shall agree to set the dates for the commission's convening through diplomatic channels.

## Article 4
### Working Group and Meeting of Experts
1. The Parties shall by mutual consent establish Working Groups of Experts that will undertake the preparation, follow-up and coordination of the Commission's meetings.

2. The meetings of the Working Group shall precede the Commission's meetings and shall be held in the same capital where the Commission's meetings are held, as mentioned in paragraph(2) of Article 5.
3. The Minister of State, Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Nigeria and the Deputy Foreign Minister of Kuwait will head their Country's delegation in the meetings of the Working Group, and it will include in its membership representatives of the Competent Authorities in the areas that the Commission will discuss in its meetings and listed on its agenda.
4. The Working Group may include in its membership a number of businessmen and members of the Chambers of Commerce and Industry in both countries, whenever the matter so requires.

## Article 5
### Commission Agenda
1. A draft Agenda for the Joint Commission Meeting shall be prepared by the host Party and transmitted to the other Party at least two months before the commencement of the meetings.
2. The Working Group shall develop recommendations to be included in the agenda, provided that these recommendations are compiled and included in the minutes of the Commission meeting.

## Article 6
### Confidentiality
The Parties shall adhere to the principle of confidentiality. All or official deliberations, documents, minutes, statements, announcements emanating from the Commission shall remain confidential and shall not be circulated or published except with the mutual Agreement of the Parties.

## Article 7
### Joint Implementation Committee
1. A Joint Implementation Committee (JIC) shall be established consisting of experts from both Parties.
2. The Joint Implementation Committee shall be chaired by a senior official of both Ministries of Foreign Affairs to implement the decisions of the annual session prior to the annual session of the following year. The meeting shall be held in the capital of the Host Country for the next Session.

3. The task of the JIC shall be to follow up the executive position of its previous decisions and to submit a Joint Report thereon to the Commission.

## Article 8
### Settlement of Disputes
Any disputes arising out of the interpretation, application or implementation of this Agreement shall be settled amicably by consultations or negotiations through diplomatic channels.

## Article 9
### Entering into force, amendments, termination
1. This Agreement shall enter into force on the date of the receipt of the last written notification through diplomatic channels by which the Parties notify each other of the completion of their internal procedures required for its entry into force.
2. This Agreement may be amended by the mutual written consent of both Parties at any time. The amendments shall enter into force in accordance with the procedure prescribed in the first paragraph of this Article.
3. This Agreement shall remain in force for a period of (5) years from the date of its entry into force and shall be renewed automatically for similar period or periods, unless one of the Parties notifies the other in writing and through diplomatic channels, about its intention to terminate it 6 months before its expiration date.
4. The termination of this Agreement, shall not affect the validity or the duration of any specific agreements, projects and activities made under this Agreement.

IN WITNESS WHEREOF, the undersigned, being duly authorized thereto by their respective Governments have signed this Agreement.
DONE in Kuwait City This Wednesday Day of 5th of February 2025, in two original copies, in the Arabic and English Languages, both texts being equally authentic.

on the grounds that the plaintiff is indebted to the defendants for sums of money, for which judgments were issued against him and enforcement proceedings were initiated against him. As the petitioner was unable to pay these debts and could not undertake amicable settlement procedures due to his complete inability to pay, this led him to file his lawsuit to obtain a ruling on his claims.
Whereas the court heard the case as set out in its session minutes, and in the session of 30/3/2022, the court ruled that it lacked subject-matter jurisdiction to hear the case and ordered its referral as is to the Bankruptcy Department <orig>إدارة الإفلاس</orig>, reserving its decision on costs.
In execution of that judgment, the case file was referred to the Bankruptcy Department <orig>إدارة الإفلاس</orig>, and the lawsuit was considered as a petition submitted to it, in accordance with Article 2 of the enacting articles of Law No. 71 of 2020 issuing the Bankruptcy Law <orig>قانون الإفلاس</orig>, and was registered with its current number. The plaintiff appeared and submitted a statement of claim to amend the form of the lawsuit by adding defendants and withdrawing the case against others, and he also submitted all documents related to his financial situation.
Whereas, based on the foregoing and guided by it, and since the last paragraph of Article 1, under the definitions clause (Debts), of the Bankruptcy Law <orig>قانون الإفلاس</orig> No. (71/2020) stipulates that (Debts subject to the supervision of the Bankruptcy Committee <orig>لجنة الإفلاس</orig>... and any other debts that the bankruptcy judge assigns the Committee to supervise, especially as the provisions of Articles (12, 13, 25) of the same law require the referral of petitions submitted to the Bankruptcy Department <orig>إدارة الإفلاس</orig> to the Bankruptcy Committee <orig>لجنة الإفلاس</orig> to undertake its affairs regarding providing an opinion on the substance of the petition, proposing the name of the trustee, and taking precautionary measures.
And whereas the response from the Bankruptcy Committee <orig>لجنة الإفلاس</orig> was received, which proposed the appointment of Mr. Ali Owaid Rekhais Awad <orig>علي عويد رخيص عوض</orig> from Al-Waha Auditing Office <orig>مكتب الواحة لتدقيق الحسابات</orig> as a trustee to inventory the debtor's assets and properties and prepare an updated financial statement, considering this a preliminary measure for him to commence his duties as trustee in accordance with the Bankruptcy Law <orig>قانون الإفلاس</orig>, and it estimated the trustee's fees for approximately 40 hours of work at a total amount of 2,000 Kuwaiti Dinars <orig>دينار كويتي</orig>.

Whereas on 23/5/2024, the judge of the Bankruptcy Department <orig>إدارة الإفلاس</orig> decided to open the bankruptcy declaration procedures for the debtor Waleed Saleh Abdullah Al-Shalaan <orig>وليد صالح عبدالله الشعلان</orig> and set the date of the petition submission, which occurred on 29/8/2021, as the provisional date for the suspension of payments. The decision was to be published and announced in the Official Gazette and the concerned parties notified thereof; Mr. Ali Owaid Rekhais Awad <orig>علي عويد رخيص عوض</orig> from Al-Waha Auditing Office <orig>مكتب الواحة لتدقيق</orig> was appointed as the bankruptcy trustee, and his fees were estimated at 2,000 K.D. from the date of issuance of this decision until the closure of the bankruptcy. He is to inventory the assets and properties of the debtor petitioner, take all necessary precautionary measures, and prepare a list of debts and a plan for liquidation and distribution.
Then, on 20/6/2024, the bankruptcy judge decided to refer the petition to the court for a ruling. In the session of 26/11/2024, the court declared the bankruptcy of the debtor Waleed Saleh Al-Shalaan <orig>وليد صالح الشعلان</orig>. This judgment has become final as it was not appealed.
Whereas the bankruptcy trustee has submitted his report on the bankruptcy proceedings and concluded that the debtor's funds are insufficient to pay his debts and are also insufficient to cover the bankruptcy fees, and requested the application of the provision of Article 135 and the closure of the bankruptcy in accordance with the provision of Article 196 of the Bankruptcy Law <orig>قانون الإفلاس</orig>.
Consequently, it is stipulated by the provision of Article 135 of the Bankruptcy Law <orig>قانون إفلاس</orig> No. 71 of 2020 that (The trustee is not obligated to conduct or complete an audit of the debts or prepare a list thereof if it becomes apparent to him that all proceeds from the sale of the debtor's assets will be used to pay the fees, charges, and costs of the proceedings.)
And it is stipulated by the provision of Article 196 of the Bankruptcy Law <orig>قانون إفلاس</orig> No. 71 of 2020 that (If the bankruptcy proceedings are suspended due to insufficient funds before the judicial composition is ratified, the bankruptcy judge may decide to close them.
The decision to close the bankruptcy due to insufficient funds results in each creditor regaining the right to take individual actions and file individual lawsuits. If the creditor's debt has been verified and accepted in the bankruptcy, he may enforce it against the debtor in accordance with the provisions of Article (195) of this Law.
The bankruptcy trustee shall be responsible for a period of one year from the date of the bankruptcy closure decision for the documents delivered to him by the creditors.)
Article 197 stipulates that (The bankrupt and any interested party may request the bankruptcy judge to reverse the decision to close the bankruptcy if it is proven that sufficient funds exist to cover the expenses of the bankruptcy proceedings, or if a sufficient amount is delivered to the trustee for that purpose.)
Article 198 stipulates that (The Bankruptcy Department <orig>إدارة الإفلاس</orig> must publish, announce, and register the decision to close the bankruptcy within five working days from the date of its issuance.)
Whereas, based on the foregoing and guided by it, and after reviewing the papers, documents, and the report submitted by the bankruptcy trustee for the bankrupt Waleed Saleh Al-Shalaan <orig>وليد صالح الشعلان</orig>, and its contents, including the financial summary of the bankruptcy and the absence of any

**Decides**

### Article One
A committee named the "Permanent Technical Committee for Establishing Accounting Rules and Auditing Guides" shall be formed, chaired by the Director of the Shareholding Companies Department, with the membership of:
1- The Budgets and Securities Controller (Shareholding Companies Department) - Vice Chairman
2- A representative from the Kuwait Association of Accountants and Auditors <orig>جمعية المحاسبين والمراجعين الكويتية</orig> - Member
3- A representative from the Capital Markets Authority <orig>هيئة أسواق المال</orig> - Member
4- A representative from the Central Bank of Kuwait <orig>بنك الكويت المركزي</orig> - Member

### Article Two
The Committee shall be responsible for deciding on registration applications submitted by concerned parties for their inclusion in the register of auditors, in its capacity as the committee responsible for registration in accordance with the provisions of Article Six of the aforementioned Decree-Law No. (103) of 2019.

### Article Three
The Committee's working system shall be as follows:
1- The Committee shall convene upon the invitation of its Chairman or their designated representative in case of absence or impediment.
2- The Committee's meeting shall be valid with the attendance of three of its members, provided that the Chairman or their deputy is among those present.
3- The Committee's decisions shall be issued by a majority of votes. In the event of a tie, the side on which the Chairman votes shall prevail.
4- The Committee may invite individuals it deems necessary to attend its meetings to participate in the discussion of a specific topic, without them having the right to vote.

### Article Four
The Registration Committee shall decide on the registration applications referred to it within thirty days from the date of their receipt, provided they are complete with all required data and documents. If the applicant is required to complete data or submit other documents, the aforementioned thirty-day period shall commence from the date the required data or documents are fully completed or submitted.
The applicant for registration shall be notified of the decision of acceptance or rejection, with reasons provided, within fifteen days from the date of its issuance.

### Article Five
The term of the Committee shall be three years, renewable for a similar period.

### Article Six
The concerned officials shall, each within their jurisdiction, implement this decision. It shall be effective from the date of its issuance, and any provisions that contradict its articles shall be repealed. It shall be published in the Official Gazette / Al-Jarida Al-Rasmiya <orig>الجريدة الرسمية</orig>.

**Minister of Commerce and Industry**
**Khalifa Abdullah Al-Ajil <orig>خليفة عبد الله العجيل</orig>**

3- Head of the Auditors' Affairs Section (representative of the Public Shareholding Companies Department), as Secretary

5- A representative from Kuwait University, as a member
6- A representative from the Public Authority for Applied Education and Training <orig>الهيئة العامة للتعليم التطبيقي والتدريب</orig>, as a member
7- A representative from the Legal Affairs Sector, as a member
8- A representative from the Kuwait Economic Society <orig>الجمعية الاقتصادية الكويتية</orig>, as a member
9- Head of the Auditors' Affairs Section (Public Shareholding Companies Department), as a member and rapporteur

The committee may seek assistance from anyone it deems appropriate from within or outside the Ministry.

### Article Two
The committee shall be responsible for the following:
1. Establishing the code of professional ethics to be adhered to in the practice of the auditing profession.
2. Determining the minimum data to be disclosed in the financial statements required for publication.
3. Periodically reviewing accounting rules and principles.
4. Conducting research and studies to develop the auditing profession.

### Article Three
The concerned officials shall, each within their jurisdiction, implement this decision. It shall come into effect from the date of its issuance, and any provisions that contradict its articles shall be repealed. It shall be published in the Official Gazette.

**Minister of Commerce and Industry**
**Khalifa Abdullah Al-Ajil <orig>خليفة عبد الله العجيل</orig>**

## Article Three
The Committee's working system shall be as follows:
1- The Committee shall convene upon the invitation of its chairman or his authorized representative in case of his absence or inability to attend.
2- The Committee's meeting shall be valid with the attendance of the majority of its members, provided that the chairman or vice-chairman, if any, is among those present.
3- The Committee may invite individuals it deems necessary to attend its meetings to participate in the discussion of a specific topic, without them having the right to vote.

## Article Four
The Committee shall, during its work, adhere to the provisions of the Auditors Law No. (103) of 2019 concerning the practice of the auditing profession and its executive regulations.

## Article Five
The term of the Committee shall be three years, renewable for a similar period.

## Article Six
The concerned officials shall, each within their jurisdiction, implement this decision. It shall come into effect from the date of its issuance, and any provisions conflicting with it shall be repealed. It shall be published in the Official Gazette.

Minister of Commerce and Industry

# Ministerial Decision No. (154) of 2025 Regarding the Addition of Commercial Activities

The Minister of Commerce and Industry,
Having reviewed:
- Decree-Law No. (68) of 1980 promulgating the Commercial Law, and its amending laws,
- And Law No. (111) of 2013 concerning Commercial Shop Licenses, and its executive regulations,
- And Decree No. (191) of 2015 concerning the organization of the Ministry of Commerce and Industry <orig>وزارة التجارة والصناعة</orig>,
- And Law No. (1) of 2016 promulgating the Companies Law, its amending laws, and its executive regulations and their amendments,
- And Council of Ministers Decision No. (285) dated 25/3/2012 regarding the recommendations of the Committee for the Unification of Commercial Classifications of Economic Activities in the State of Kuwait,
- And Ministerial Decision No. (689) of 2018 concerning the unification of the statistical data classification for economic activities in government agencies using the United Nations International Standard Industrial Classification of All Economic Activities (ISIC), Revision 4, as internationally recommended by the United Nations Statistics Division and as agreed upon within the framework of the Gulf Cooperation Council countries,
- And Administrative Decision No. (679) of 2025 concerning the formation of the Committee for the Classification of Commercial, Professional, and Craft Activities,
- And the minutes of meeting No. (14) of the Committee for the Classification of Commercial, Professional, and Craft Activities, held on 7/7/2025, and meeting No. (15) held on 10/7/2025, regarding the addition of new activities.
- And upon the submission of the Undersecretary of the Ministry,
- And based on the requirements of the public interest.

**Has decided**

### (Article One)
The activities listed in the schedule attached to this decision, numbering (2), shall be added to the commercial activities within the limits applicable in the Unified Guide for the Classification of Economic Activities in the Gulf Cooperation Council countries.

### (Article Two)
All concerned officials – each within their jurisdiction – shall implement this decision. It shall come into effect from the date of its issuance and shall be published in the Official Gazette.

Minister of Commerce and Industry
Khalifa Abdullah Al-Ajil <orig>خليفة عبدالله العجيل</orig>

Issued on: 9 Safar 1447 H

# Ministry of Interior <orig>وزارة الداخلية</orig>
## (Ministerial Decision No. 1386 of 2025)
Regarding: The entry of a foreigner residing in one of the Gulf Cooperation Council countries into the country with a tourist entry visa granted directly at the port of entry
The First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Interior
- Having reviewed Decree-Law No. 114 of 2024 concerning the Foreigners' Residence Law.
- And Ministerial Decision No. 1228 of 2008, and its amendments, regarding allowing a foreigner residing in one of the Gulf Cooperation Council countries to enter the country with a tourist entry visa granted directly at the port of entry.
- And based on the proposal of the Acting Undersecretary of the Ministry.
Has decided
### Article (1)
Without prejudice to the provisions of the aforementioned Decree-Law No. 114 of 2024, a foreigner residing in one of the Gulf Cooperation Council countries – who holds a valid residency of not less than six months – may enter the country with a tourist entry visa granted directly at the port of entry.
### Article (2)
The aforementioned Ministerial Decision No. 1228 of 2008 is hereby repealed, as is any provision that contravenes or conflicts with the provisions of this decision.
### Article (3)
The Acting Undersecretary of the Ministry shall implement this decision, and it shall come into force from the date of its publication in the Official Gazette.
First Deputy Prime Minister
and Minister of Interior
Fahad Yousuf Saud Al-Sabah <orig>فهد يوسف سعود الصباح</orig>
Issued on: 12 Safar 1447 H
Corresponding to: 6 August 2025 G

## Resolution No. PAI (110) of 2025 Regarding the Closure of a Plot
The Acting Director General
Having reviewed:

- Ministerial Resolution No. (5/2025) issued on 9/3/2025, authorizing the Director General of the Public Authority for Industry <orig>الهيئة العامة للصناعة</orig> to impose the penalties of warning and closure on violating industrial projects.
- The violation report submitted by the Disturbed Areas Section No. (32), issued on 21/07/2025, which states that Mr. Daham Munawer Baffan Al-Enezi <orig>دحام مناور بفان العنزي</orig> committed the following violations:
    - Dividing and leasing the plot.
    - Encroaching outside the plot's boundaries by an area of 60 meters.
- And based on the presentation by the Deputy Director General for Standards and Industrial Services.
And in the public interest.

### It has been decided
#### (Article One)
To close Plot No. (597) located in the South Amghara <orig>جنوب أمغره</orig> area - Block (1) - belonging to Mr. Daham Munawer Baffan Al-Enezi <orig>دحام مناور بفان العنزي</orig>, until the violations and their resulting effects are removed.

#### (Article Two)
In the event the violation is not removed within (one) month from the date of closure, a more severe penalty shall be imposed.

#### (Article Three)
This resolution shall be published in the Official Gazette and shall be effective from the date of its issuance. The concerned authorities shall implement it, each within its jurisdiction.

Acting Director General of the Public Authority for Industry <orig>مدير عام الهيئة العامة للصناعة بالتكليف</orig>
